intro: Cacalia pulchella, commonly known as the pretty beggar's-tick, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. Its small, yellow flowers are clustered in a spherical shape, and it has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. Cacalia pulchella is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a short-lived perennial.
